title: Tech tally: What campaigns learned in 2014
content:
Twitter is an obsession for many 2014 midterm political campaign staff . Tech tally : What campaigns learned
Tuesday ’ s midterms are shaping up to be a great political tech equalizer .
Both parties head into the final hours of the 2014 campaign bragging about their enhanced ability to keep tabs on who has requested and returned absentee ballots . Democrats and Republicans have the data and are spending millions of dollars targeting last-minute TV and online advertising toward niche audiences like baseball fans and even Gilligan 's Island insomniacs . They can also track what ’ s trending on Twitter from Little Rock to Denver , honing their campaign message to deal with the unexpected .
Typically , great political tech innovations debut during a White House campaign when there ’ s plenty of money and manpower to spare .
But while little truly groundbreaking has been deployed on the election front in 2014 , campaign strategists from both sides of the aisle have ripped from President Barack Obama ’ s old campaign playbooks and pushed out their own scaled-down digital tools in this year ’ s key House , Senate and gubernatorial races .
“ There ’ s really no off-year anymore , ” said Gerrit Lansing , the National Republican Congressional Committee ’ s digital director . “ You can ’ t afford to take a quarter or two off in terms of pushing the envelope for what ’ s best . ”
Whether the Democrats can hold onto the tech advantage they ’ d built in 2012 remains an open question , and it ’ s one that won ’ t be resolved even if the party loses its Senate majority on Election Day . After all , the 2016 presidential race is right on the horizon and both parties are about to be tested again on a much larger playing field .
With the obvious caveats tied to a midterm election , here ’ s a look at five ways Democratic and Republican campaigns have been building off Obama ’ s technology lessons in search of the upper hand in 2014 :
This cycle has proven there ’ s very little politicians won ’ t do for a donation .
Sure , email fundraising has been around for a while . But House Democrats have taken things to an entirely new level in 2014 with a relentless stream of ‘ sky-is-falling ’ missives seeking to jolt donors into giving with URGENT warnings about what will happen if Republicans gain control of both chambers in Congress .
Critics warn that the velocity and tenor of so many terror-stricken emails — Republicans are doing it too — isn ’ t sustainable . “ You ’ ve seen an unprecedented race to the bottom , ” said Obama ’ s 2012 digital director , Teddy Goff .
But while the messages have provided ample fodder for late-night television comedy , they ’ ve also been a very successful new revenue stream for both parties . “ We are funding our ads today , the vast majority today , through digital means , ” Matt Canter , the deputy executive director at the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee , said during a recent panel discussion on the midterms at Google ’ s Washington headquarters .
It ’ s not just email where campaigns are finding technology can help them raise cash .
Both parties have figured out over the last two years how to make the donation process a simpler online experience — from storing names , addresses and credit card information to already having a specific dollar amount listed in the email based on what someone previously gave .
While there remain plenty of missed opportunities on the mobile front , House Republicans say their one-click system was a key aspect in helping raise as much in September as they did in the entire 2012 cycle . On the left , the PayPal-like ActBlue system has brought in more than 5 million donations this cycle .
Most candidate websites are now in on the act too by tracking a visitor ’ s log-in location . Out-of-state visitors are seen as more likely to donate and commonly get met first with a pitch for money . Someone from inside the state ’ s borders is seen as a potential voter and can often access a biography or issue page without first getting hit up for cash .
Campaigns are playing a cat-and-mouse game trying to keep up with voters ’ ever-changing media habits .
Skipping live television ? Candidates can now air commercials to specific groups of people streaming their favorite sitcoms , movies and news through the web . Using your phone to follow Twitter or Facebook comments during a ball game ? Social media ads can be tailored to targets too .
There ’ s more than meets the eye for how the campaigns make the connections they do with these online voters .
Both Democrats and Republicans have spent the last two years scrubbing their voter files and other consumer data , trying to match specific persuadable supporters with their specific web habits . The parties are also looking for inexpensive ways to find voters who live in expensive TV markets and also in parts of a state or congressional district that is primarily fed by a media market located in a neighboring state . Ads aren ’ t just going up on YouTube and local newspapers anymore either . Just as popular : sports and gossip sites .
And even if someone tries to erase their online web history by turning off the cookie function , campaigns are using their databases to find a targeted person ’ s home and then message them through the specifically-assigned address for each device on an internet network .
Matthew Dybwad , a GOP digital strategist , said such sophisticated voter targeting is “ really something that ’ s only been fully realized this cycle ” as the data gets more carefully vetted . “ We ’ re using it in a default position in every race we ’ re running , ” he said .
